text:
Thanks for the link. Learnt all about breathing last night!  Caused by cheaper (non cinematographic) lenses apparently - good thing to know about. That fudge sounds ingenious. I'll make sure to watch it a good few times before starting cleanup.
Only have Nuke for denoising (or any fancy nukepedia nodes I can find). Maybe Neat have a trial...

My Mac seems happy enough with the file. I've written out the relevant frames so hopefully there shouldn't be any issues. Just found Tony Lyons ( <https://compositingmentor.com/category/gizmostools/> ) - some good tuts on there. Lots more to learn - but at least more of it is making sense now!

attachments.title: gizmos/tools – Compositing Mentor
attachments.text: explaining and publishing gizmos and tools for nuke

text: Tony Lyons stuff is really good, he explains everything very well, I watched all his videos through youtube, that looks like a new website for him. In regards to Neatvideo, the node they made is called 'reduce noise' on Nuke and is basically the industry standard. Pretty much most of the companies use it, but I think it is fairly ecpensive

One thing I would suggest, you mentioned about denoising. I know some people denoise the whole plate and regrain at the end. I'm not sure what practice they have told you, but the best practice is to retain as much of the original grain in the plate as possible and only regrain the area you have fixed
Ok, I'll try that. We were taught to denoise / degrain the whole shot then rematch using the best match in the different channels.
Yup. You're right, Neat is pretty pricey! Startup costs for a vfx shop must be pretty nerve-racking!

sorry might have confused things, definitely denoise the whole plate, but the end result you want to retain as much of the original grain as possible in areas of the plate you haven't worked on. If you can accurately match the grain for the whole thing maybe that might be okay for this, but in the industry, especially the bigger companies, they will insist on retaining as much of the original plate as possible. Where shots are completely cg that's a different story you definitely add grain to whole thing
